newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Bank of China seeks no special HK deals.
newsitem.headline: Bank of China seeks no special HK deals.

text.p: Chinese banking giant the Bank of China Group in Hong Kong and Macau (BOC) will seek no special treatment in Hong Kong after the territory reverts to Chinese rule from July 1, a senior official said on Friday.
"We seek no privileges after 1997...it is not our intention to replace any bank in the territory," said Clarina Man, a deputy general manager with the public relations division.
"We will just compete on a level-playing field, on an equal footing and after July 1, business in Hong Kong will be the same as before," she told Reuters in an interview.
Hong Kong, a British colony of over 150 years, reverts to China at midnight on June 30.

In the 1984 Sino-British treaty governing the handover, China pledged Hong Kong a considerable degree of self-rule and complete fiscal independence under a "one country, two systems" formula espoused by China's late paramount leader Deng Xiaoping.

But many Hong Kong people are concerned about an emergence of cronyism and meddling by Chinese officials and companies in Hong Kong affairs and that Beijing, however well-meaning, might be unable to control that.
Man said BOC was acutely aware of such concerns and was particularly sensitive that it must vigilantly observe the "one country, two systems" formula, and be seen to do so.
"We are very sensitive and mindful of the 'one China, two systems' formula...foreign and local banks will be treated equally (after the handover)," she said.
